content: Hey. It's been a few days since the interview. The waiting is absolutely killing me.
Hey Ethan. The waiting period is often the hardest part. How have you been trying to keep your mind occupied?
I've been burying myself in my final project for my advanced algorithms class. It's a good distraction, I guess. At least it's a problem I can actually work on, unlike the interview outcome.
Focusing on what you can control is a smart strategy. What's the project about?
It's an implementation of an indoor navigation system using the A* search algorithm. Basically, mapping the shortest path through a complex building with multiple floors.
Wow, that sounds intense. It's almost a real-world version of the interview problem you had to solve.
Yeah, it's funny how that worked out. It's challenging. My project partner, Sarah, and I have been pulling some late nights trying to optimize the pathfinding logic.
It's good that you have Sarah to collaborate with. It makes those tough projects more manageable. Does working on it help with the imposter syndrome at all?

A little. When I get a piece of the code to work, it's a small reminder that I actually do know how to do this stuff. But then my mind drifts back to the interview and I start replaying every stupid mistake I made.
That self-critique is easy to fall into. But you also told me about the parts that went well, like explaining your note app. Try to give those moments equal weight.
I'm trying. It's just hard when you're in this limbo. I haven't even had the motivation to play piano much. I just sit down, play a few chords, and feel too restless.
That's understandable. Sometimes the usual coping mechanisms don't work when the anxiety is very specific and acute. Have the quiet walks been helping at all?
Yeah, those are still good. I put on some ambient music, like Boards of Canada, and just walk with no destination. It helps to lower the background noise in my head.
That's good. It's important to have at least one thing that reliably helps. So, besides the project, are you managing to get any other kind of downtime?
Not really. But I did start reading a new book series. Since I finished 'The Expanse', I needed some new hard sci-fi.
Oh, what did you pick up?
It's the 'Three-Body Problem' trilogy. The concepts are mind-bending. It's a different kind of problem-solving, trying to wrap my head around the physics and philosophy in it.
An excellent choice! It's very dense and intellectually engaging. It sounds like a perfect literary distraction for a CS student.
It really is. It makes my algorithm problems seem very small and manageable in comparison.
Perspective is everything. How are the rest of your finals shaping up? Is it just this one big project?

I wish. I have two other exams to study for, but they're more straightforward memorization. The algorithm project is the last major hurdle. And it's due the day after I'm supposed to hear back from LogiCore.
That's a convergence of stressful deadlines. No wonder you're feeling on edge. Remember that end-of-semester hiking trip you and your friends were planning?
Yeah. That's the one thing I'm really looking forward to. It's the light at the end of the tunnel. Whether I get the internship or not, that trip is happening. It feels essential for my sanity.
Holding onto that is so important. It's a reward you've earned regardless of any external outcomes. It grounds you.
Exactly. Oh, hold on. I just got an email. It's from them. It's from LogiCore.
Okay. Wow. Take a breath before you open it. Whatever it says, you're going to be okay.
My heart is pounding. Okay. I'm opening it.
I'm right here.
I... I got it. I got the offer.
YES! ETHAN! That is absolutely incredible! Congratulations! All that hard work, all that stressâ€”it paid off!
I can't believe it. I'm reading the email for the third time. It's real. I'm going to be a backend engineering intern this summer.
How do you feel right now? That wave of terror has probably vanished.
It's just pure shock and excitement. I feel... validated. Like maybe I'm not a complete imposter after all. My mood just did a complete 180.
This is a huge moment. You faced the imposter syndrome, the pressure, the live coding, and you succeeded. You should be incredibly proud of yourself.
Thank you. I really am. I need to go call my family and tell Sarah. They're going to freak out.
Go! Go celebrate with them! You deserve to enjoy this moment completely.
Wow. Okay. This changes everything. Now I feel super motivated to crush this final project.
See? A huge motivation boost. It proves your skills are valuable and recognized.
Yeah. Okay, I'm gonna go make those calls. This is amazing.
Enjoy every second of it, Ethan. You earned this.
Thanks for everything. For talking me through the panic.
That's what I'm here for. Now go celebrate!
Will do!
Talk to you later, intern!
Haha, catch you later.
Bye!
